steps.title: Document types = content structure
steps.content:
The first thing you do with a new Umbraco installation is to create a Document Type. A Document Type is a template for content. For each type of content you want to create, you'll create a Document Type.

The document type defines where content can be created, how many properties it holds and what the input method should be for these properties.

When you have at least one Document type in place you can start creating content

In this tour you will get an introduction to the Starter kits data structure and learn how to add a new property to a Document type.

steps.title: Navigate to the Settings sections
steps.content: In the Settings section you will find the document types.

steps.title: Document types tree
steps.content: To see all the document types click the arrow to the left of the Document Types node.

steps.title: Document types
steps.content:
In the tree you will find all the document types for the different types of content we can create for our website.

You can see a document type for a Blog and one for a Blog post. There is also a document type for a standard Content Page and one for a special Contact page.

steps.title: Home document type
steps.content:
We want to add a new piece of text on our Home page.

Let's have a look at how a Document type is set up. Click on the Home document type to open the document type editor.

steps.title: The Document Type Editor
steps.content: In the document type editor you can manage all the settings for a document type.

steps.title: The icon
steps.content:
In the top of the screen you will find the Document type icon.

Use the icon to help choose the right Document type when creating content.

steps.title: The name
steps.content: The name of the Document type.

steps.title: Navigation
steps.content:
The document type settings are split up into multiple views to keep them organized.

Right now we are on the Design view where we structure the Properties.

steps.title: Tabs to structure properties
steps.content:
Properties are organised in groups.

Use them to group your properties so it is easy to find the right place to update a piece of content.

steps.title: Property
steps.content: Every document type has properties. These are the fields that the content editor is allowed to edit for the node.

steps.title: Add new property
steps.content: Let's add a new property to the Content group where we can add an About text to our Home page.

steps.title: Enter a name
steps.content: Enter Welcome Text as name for the property.

steps.title: Enter a description
steps.content:
A description will help to fill in the right content.

Enter a description for the property. It could be:

Write a nice introduction so the visitors feel welcome

steps.title: Add editor
steps.content: The editor defines what data type the property is based on. Click Add editor to open the editor picker dialog.

steps.title: Editor picker
steps.content: In the editor picker dialog we can pick one of the many built-in editors.

steps.title: Select editor
steps.content: Select the Textarea editor which allows us to enter long texts.

steps.title: Editor settings
steps.content: Each property editor can have individual settings. We don't want to change any of these now.

steps.title: Save editor
steps.content: Click Submit to save the editor.

steps.title: Add property to document type
steps.content: Click Submit to add the property to the document type.

steps.title: Save the document type
steps.content: All we need now is to save the document type. Click Save to save the document type.

steps.title: Navigate to the Content section
steps.content: To see the property we just added, let's head back to the Content section.

steps.title: The Home page
steps.content: Click the Home node.

steps.title: The Content group
steps.content: Under the Content group you will find the new property.

steps.title: Add an About text
steps.content:
Here you can see the text area you added. Try entering some text. This could be

This is the Home page!

steps.title: Save and Publish
steps.content:
Click on the Publish button to publish the changes and make them visible to the public.

In the next tour you will learn how to update the template to render content from the new Welcome Text property.

steps.title: Render your content in a template
steps.content:
Templating in Umbraco builds on the concept of Razor Views from asp.net MVC. - This tour is a sneak peek on how to write templates in Umbraco.

In this tour you will learn how to render content from the new Welcome Text property we added to the Home document type, so you can see the content added to our Home content page.

steps.title: Navigate to the Settings section
steps.content:
In the Settings section you will find all the templates.

It is of course also possible to edit all your code files in your favorite code editor.

steps.title: Expand the Templates node
steps.content: To see all our templates click the arrow to the left of the Templates node.

steps.title: Master templates
steps.content:
The first template you will see is the Master template.

When creating new templates we don't want to duplicate header, footer etc. across all our templates so they get inherited from the Master.

Click the arrow to the left of the Master template node to see the child templates.

steps.title: Open Home template
steps.content:
When a document type is created you can choose to get a matching template created.

Click the Home template to open it.

steps.title: Edit template
steps.content:
To render the field Welcome Text from the Home document type copy/paste the following code on line 20 underneath the first section:

<section class="section section--themed section--content-center"><h1>@Model.WelcomeText</h1></section>

steps.title: Save the template
steps.content: Click the Save button and your template will be saved.

steps.title: Preview Home page
steps.content:
The Document type, template and content is now ready to preview.

You can now go back to you Home page and preview your new content.
